Comments: This paper underwent a light edit by SIAM staff prior to posting.

Assumption: The typical commute for a majority of the population is short.
For a given distance, time is distributed normally.
The maximum drive length is 2860 miles
The short/medium and medium/long distance divisions are 8.25 miles and 30 miles respectively.
The short-medium and medium-long time divisions are 10 minutes and 30 minutes.
Simplification: Each driver will fall into only one distance-time category.
Model: Normal distribution curves for time, given distance categories (short, medium, long), with means and standard deviations derived from data and assumptions.
Sensitivity Analysis: The upper bound on the distance function has no effect as the function's value decreases to near zero values beyond a distance of 20 miles. The constants in the distance function, however, were very sensitive to change.
Strength and Weakness: Drivers cannot be reasonably categorized into having typical driving any category; all drivers take trips of many different lengths.
Our model had a weaker correlation between time and distance than the dataset.

Assumption: People make judgments based on cost.
People will walk until the perceived value of walking is equal to the cheapest possible taxi service to bring them from their current position to their desired location.
Commuter preferences have remained relatively constant since 1967.
There are no discounts (e.g., student discounts, promotions, etc.).
Commuters only return their rideshare once per day. (Round Trip)
The average commuter has the car for 9 hours and 45 and Y minutes on weekdays, where Y is the time required to walk back to the station where his or her car is parked. (Round Trip)
The average commuter takes the car out twice on weekends for a duration of four hours and Y minutes. (Round Trip)
The time spent inside the station is negligible. (Round Trip)
The cars follow an L-shaped snake geometry to travel between points. (Round Trip)
No pickups and drop-offs will occur at airports. (Round Trip)
No taxes. (Round Trip)
All stations are operational (cars are present when they are needed and space is available when someone needs to park). (One-Way Station)
Time spent waiting in stations is 0 minutes. (One-Way Station)
Stations are within walking distance of the destination. (One-Way Station)
Average person commutes 2 trips per day. (One-Way Station)
Cars receive “superpermits” to park in any residential, metered, or general spot for free. (One-Way Free-Floating)
Users can find parking spots available near their destination. (One-Way Free-Floating)
Users do not need to walk to get from their car do the destination. (One-Way Free-Floating)
Free-floating car users take short trips. (One-Way Free-Floating)
Consumers will walk to the nearest available car. (One-Way Free-Floating)
Although it is a one-way system, most consumers will still take two trips on a daily basis (One-Way Free-Floating)
The insurance cost per car stays the same even if multiple people are sharing that car. (Fractional Ownership)
Three people share each car. (Fractional Ownership)
Gasoline prices stay constant. (Fractional Ownership)
People drive as much when they car share compared to not car-sharing. (Fractional Ownership)
Model: Cost\_uberX,total \= $1.05 \+ $9.00 hr^-1 \* t\_drive \+ $0.70 mile^-1 \* d \+ $6.81 hr^-1 \* (t\_drive \+ 0.133) (UberX Cost)
Equating UberX cost and walking cost to find maximum walking distance/time.
Round Trip Car-Sharing: Implicit cost calculation based on walking time and perceived cost of walking. Explicit cost based on Zipcar's pricing model.
One-Way Car-Sharing Station Model: Implicit cost similar to round trip, but for one leg. Explicit cost based on fees.
One-Way Car-Sharing Free-Floating Model: Cost to find car based on car density and walking cost. Trip cost based on Car2Go pricing.
Fractional Ownership: Cost/year \= (repairs \+ insurance \+ payment)/number of people \+ 365\*38.4\*(miles/day)\*gas price.
Results: Fractional ownership is the cheapest, followed by one-way floating, one-way station, and round trip.
Among the four cities, Knoxville, TN is the cheapest for fractional ownership, followed by Richmond, VA; Poughkeepsie, NY; and Riverside, CA.
Strength and Weakness: Many bikesharing programs, which are one-way station systems, have had issues keeping stations from becoming full or empty, which create the undesirable scenarios of not being able to park or not having a bike to ride... With cars, however, this is significantly less possible because a unique driver is required for each car \[6\]. This greatly increases the cost of implementation.

Assumption: In the future, 100% of vehicles are electric and autonomous.
The electricity infrastructure does not significantly change over the next few decades.
Completely switching from conventional to electric cars reduces greenhouse gases by 33%.
Autonomous vehicles eliminate the need to walk to a station.
Electric cars cost $0.05 to drive per mile.
The cost of maintaining electric vehicles is 1/3 that of conventional cars.

The total costs associated with air pollutants in the US is estimated at anywhere from US$71 billion to $277 billion per year. For simplicity, we will take the lower bound of that estimate, US$71 billion.
The number of licensed US drivers remains constant at 210M.
The cost of ride sharing does not change.
Insurance premiums for autonomous cars will decrease by 66%.
Model: One-Way Car-Sharing Model: Explicit cost \= $84.00 \+ 1825hours \* $x/hour, where x is the half-hour car-sharing rate. Total cost \= implicit cost \+ explicit cost.
Round Trip Car-Sharing Model: Devolves into the one-way model with autonomous vehicles.
Fractional Ownership Model: cost/year \= (repairs \+ insurance \+ payment)/number of people \+ 365\*(days/year)\*38.4\*(miles/day)\*$.05/mile
Results: Fractional ownership remains the cheapest option.
